title: 108_hr4851
content:
Step 1 - Extractively Summarize the curr_chunk, try to preserve key details, and condense the text by removing irrelevant words:

"S."

Step 4: Output the summarized chunk

"S." The text discusses amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding spending limitations in budget resolutions for fiscal years. It introduces a new requirement for consistency with specified spending limits and establishes a point of order against resolutions that do not comply. Waivers can only be granted with a two-thirds majority vote in the House of Representatives or the Senate. The text introduces a new requirement for consistency with specified spending limits in budget resolutions for fiscal years. Waivers can only be granted with a two-thirds majority vote in the House of Representatives or the Senate. SEC. 13. REDUCTION OF FICA RATES RESULTING FROM PERSONAL SOCIAL SECURITY SAVINGS PROGRAM. Employee Contribution section 3101 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reduce the tax rate on employees for Old-Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance. The reduction percentage is based on the OASDI rate ratio exceeding 125 percent in a transition year following the termination year. The Prosperity Act of 2004 defines the reduction percentage as the difference between the rate in effect for the reduction year and the rate needed for the OASDI rate ratio to be 125 percent. The OASDI rate ratio is the combined balance in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund at the end of a calendar year. The Prosperity Act of 2004 defines the reduction percentage as the difference between the rate in effect for the reduction year and the rate needed for the OASDI rate ratio to be 125 percent. The OASDI rate ratio is the combined balance in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund at the end of a calendar year. The Act also includes limitations on reduction and amendments to the Employer Contribution section of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Prosperity Act of 2004 defines the reduction percentage as the difference between the rate in effect for the reduction year and the rate needed for the OASDI rate ratio to be 125 percent. Limitations on reduction are included in the Employer Contribution section of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Prosperity Act of 2004 defines the reduction percentage as the difference between the rate in effect for the reduction year and the rate needed for the OASDI rate ratio to be 125 percent. Limitations on reduction are included in the Employer Contribution section of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, where the rate of tax imposed under subsection (a) shall be reduced by the reduction percentage in certain years, with a limitation to prevent it from falling below 9.9 percent.
